description.narrative: This project will conserve biodiversity and ecosystem services in three critical landscapes of the Central Forest Spine, by supporting the country’s CFS Master Plan to restore connectivity between forest complexes.

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative:
- Natural forest of 4 forest blocks of CFS protected and managed well (Main Range Forest Complex, Southeast Pahang Peat Swamp Forest, Greater Taman Negara complex, Endau-Rompin-Sedili complex)
- Funds for CFS conservation developed and invested (apart from GEF funds)
- Overall score of CFS Capacity Development Scorecard raised

comment.narrative:
- 4.5 million ha of PRF and National Park in CFS complexes
- Currently mostly government or ad hoc NGO funding
- Current capacity score card is 12

1)No net loss of forested area , with 95% remaining natural forest 2) 3 scopes of technical inputs namely biodiversity, ecosystem services and carbon stocks developed 3) One tool for monitoring of biodiversity, ecosystem services and/or carbon stocks developed 4) Tiger population in CFS landscape remains unchanged. At least 50% of the enforcement staff’s time is allocated for enforcement work. The job scope (Senarai Tugas) of these enforcement staff is complied with. At least 15% of recorded wildlife and forestry crime cases are prosecuted in court and given the legally stated penalties. 5) List of powers under WCA 2010 to be delegated to state forestry officers and state park officers agreed by DWNP. At least five forestry officers and state park officers involved in three integrated enforcement activities annually (One per target site). 6)At least five community rangers appointed by administration/legal means in targeted landscape. One community effectively undertake wildlife monitoring and enforcement in targeted landscape. One WildFriend programme developed at one target state 7) One decision-making paper prepared for a common data sharing. One state identified to pilot SMART based patrolling and SMART patrolling training of staff conducted. At least four SOP(s) related to arresting, handling of seized item, investigation and prosecution for state parks developed. Assessment of different types of intelligence technologies undertaken and the type of technology to be identified and procured. 8) A systematic capacity building programme related to either monitoring of biodiversity, ecosystem services or carbon stocks developed for targeted CFS landscapes 9) One CFS management plan for targeted landscape drafted. 10) At least 400 ha of degraded forest landscapes in line with ARR methodology, using a mix of native species, in accordance with current plans within the CFSMP rehabilitated. 11) At least 20,000 ha of critical corridor areas identified and gazetted at the three targeted states. 12) At least 2 district local plans incorporate the relevant ecological corridors. 13) At least 50 indigenous peoples involved in livelihood related projects in Taman Negara, Belum-Temengor and Endau-Rompin. Household income survey of indigenous people initiated in the piloted projects to establish household income baseline. 14) Baseline studies for economic losses due to HEC within the indigenous communities initiated. Scope of work to develop the guidelines for non-consumptive wildlife tourism in HEC area developed. One target HEC site identified for non-consumptive wildlife tourism. 15) Standard training programme for sustainable forest landscape management initiated. One training module for non-consumptive wildlife tourism programme developed. One CFS Communications Plan (e.g. awareness and advocacy strategy) in Forestry Department Peninsular Malaysia drafted. One dedicated CFS Counterpart Officer at each state. Drafting of communications programme for CBOs initiated. 16) At least USD500,000 acquired from new and additional sources of funding for CFS. At least 1 additional MOU/MOA for funding sources signed between donor and receiver 17) At least one entity established to collect and disburse funds for conservation and sustainable management of CFS. Trustee membership to include non-governmental organisation and transparent governance measures. Development of budgeting criteria to disburse funds for CFS related activities initiated. Development of eligibility criteria for traditional and non-traditional stakeholders to access the funds initiated. 18) GoM continue to allocate on an annual basis funding for CFSMP implementation. Outcome-based budgeting criteria for CFS funding for technical agencies developed. Monitoring and reporting mechanism for the CFS funding is established for the state. Information on economic valuation of the CFS landscape is available for one state. 19) CFS sustainable finance plan for one state initiated.

On top of the key milestones set up by UNDP-NCE (refer above), the targets as per revised Strategic Results Framework are: 1) Slight decrease (0.88%) in the total forested area within Central Forest Spine landscapes. The total forest area for Peninsular Malaysia in 2015 was 5,758,165 ha. The total area in 2019 was 5,707,289 ha. Thus, the total forest area has experienced a slight reduction of 50,786 ha or a reduction of 0.88%. 2) One scope namely the biodiversity protocol has been developed to be incorporated into decision making papers 3) One tool for monitoring of biodiversity has been developed for federal and state technical agencies and stakeholders. 4) Tiger population in CFS landscape remains unchanged. More than 15% of recorded wildlife and forestry crime cases have been prosecuted in court and given the legally stated penalties. The percentage of enforcement staff doing enforcement work in the landscape is available. The job scope (Senarai Tugas) of enforcement staff is complied with. 5) The List of powers under Wildlife Conservation Act (WCA) 2010 to be delegated to state forestry officers and state park officers has been agreed by DWNP. More than ten forestry officers and state park officers have been involved in more than three integrated enforcement activities annually. 6) A total of 15 community rangers have been appointed by administration/legal means in targeted landscape. b) More than one community effectively undertake wildlife monitoring and enforcement in targeted landscape. One WildFriend programme has been developed at one target state. 7) One decision-making paper initiated for a common data sharing. One state has been identified to pilot SMART based patrolling and SMART patrolling training of staff has been conducted. The development of four SOP(s) related to arresting, handling of seized item, investigation and prosecution for state parks completed as planned. Assessment of different types of intelligence technologies has been undertaken and the type of technology to be identified and procured. 8) A systematic capacity building programme related to monitoring of biodiversity has been implemented for targeted CFS landscapes. DWNP and Forestry Department are capacity built for wildlife and forestry crime monitoring, intelligence, investigation and prosecution at federal and state levels. 9) A draft management plan has been developed for one (1) ecological corridor namely Panti-Ulu Sedili in Johor. 10) More than 400 ha of degraded forest landscapes in line with ARR methodology, using a mix of native species, in accordance with current plans within the CFS Master Plan has been rehabilitated 11) More than 20,000 ha of critical corridor areas identified and gazetted at the three targeted states. 12) Four (4) district local plans have incorporated the relevant ecological corridors. 13) 111 indigenous peoples are involved in livelihood related projects in Taman Negara, Belum-Temengor and Endau-Rompin. Household income survey of indigenous people in the piloted projects to establish household income baseline has started. 14) Baseline studies for economic losses due to HEC within the indigenous communities has initiated. Scope of work for the guidelines for non-consumptive wildlife tourism in HEC area has been developed. One target HEC site has been identified for non-consumptive wildlife tourism. 15) Standard training programme for sustainable forest landscape management focusing on eco-tourism has been initiated. One training module for non-consumptive wildlife tourism programme has been initated. One CFS Communications Plan (e.g. awareness and advocacy strategy) in Forestry Department Peninsular Malaysia developed. One dedicated CFS Counterpart Officer at each state has been appointed. One effective communications programme for CBOs has been identified. 16) More than USD500,000 (RM 2 million) has been acquired from new and additional sources of funding for CFS. One additional MOU for funding sources signed between Yayasan Hasanah and FDPM. 17) One entity has been established to collect and disburse funds for conservation and sustainable management of CFS. Trustee membership to include non-governmental organisation and transparent governance measures. Development of budgeting criteria to disburse funds for CFS related activities has been initiated. Development of eligibility criteria for traditional and non-traditional stakeholders to access the funds initiated. 18) GoM continues to allocate on an annual basis funding for CFS Master Plan implementation since 2011. Outcome-based budgeting criteria for CFS funding for technical agencies have been developed under Five-Year Development Plans (RMK). Monitoring and reporting mechanism for the CFS funding is established for the state. Information on economic valuation of the CFS landscape is available for Perak. 19) CFS sustainable finance plan for Perak has initiated.

The Strategic Results Framework (SRF) and Adaptive Management Action Plan were revised and finalized in consultation with KATS and UNDP Country Office and Regional Technical Adviser. The SRF was endorsed by the Project Steering Committee (PSC) on 23rd September 2019. The project will submit extension request by March 2020.

Project exceptional extension request up 43 months has been submitted to UNDP-NCE Executive Coordinators approval at the end of March 2020. Awaiting for official communication on the project extension request.

The project received conditional extension approval on 13 May 2020 from UNDP Nature, Climate and Energy (UNDP-NCE) until 31 December 2023 with the extension for year 2022 and 2023 is conditioned upon the project’s achievement of key milestones agreed for year 2021 and 2022. The key milestones to obtain extension for year 2022 are: • Project Implementation Review rated as Moderately Satisfactory or higher • Mid Term Review rated as Moderately Satisfactory or higher overall with sustainability rated as Moderately Likely or higher • Monitoring tool for biodiversity, ecosystem services and carbon stocks developed • Integrated SMART patrolling initiative piloted in one State • Management plan for Johor (Panti - Ulu Sedili) ecological corridor developed • CFS sustainable finance plan for one state drafted

1 75% of the MTR recommendations taken on as part of the management response in flight with 25% completed. July 2022
Request that PIR 2022 evaluation be undertaken for progress achieved in the period of assessment only namely mid-2021 to mid-2022. This include both achievement of outcomes and outputs as well as expenditure. A new projection of expenditure needs to be developed beginning at the reactivation of the project in May 2020. However, UNDP indicated that one of the KPIs used for UNDP-supported GEF-funded project is cumulative project expenditure since project document signature date.
The end of project target at objective level concerning “no net loss on forest cover” to be reviewed. However, UNDP indicated that project objective committed during PIF and signed Project Document is the terms and condition of which GEF is providing grant to the IC-CFS project, which could not be revised and adjusted.
2 2022 PIR rated as MS or higher.
1) Management plan for Johor (Panti - Ulu Sedili) ecological corridor piloted and a governance mandate agreed for its monitoring. 2) Integrated SMART patrolling initiative institutionalized within the FDPM and piloted in three States. 3) CFS sustainable finance plan for one state drafted and commitment from State on piloting one financial mechanism therein. 4) Community-based wildlife monitoring programme. 5) Management plan for Pahang (Sungai Yu – Tanum) and Perak (Belum – Temengor) ecological corridor developed. 6) Outcome-based budgeting criteria finalized and communicated to all States. 7) Results from socio-economic study used to determine livelihood projects and at least one intervention activated in Perak or Johor. 8) 1 decision making paper informed by the biodiversity monitoring protocol tool submitted to the targeted state/federal council/Cabinet for approval. 9) 50% of enforcement staff deployed to patrol duty in the field as opposed to desk duty. 10) SMART based patrolling system is developed, adopted, implemented and data shared by DWNP, state forestry, state parks and other related stakeholders at 3 target states. 11) SMART based patrolling system is developed, adopted, implemented and data shared by DWNP, state forestry, state parks and other related stakeholders at 3 target states. 12) Monitoring tool for biodiversity developed into a module as part of the Project’s standard training programme and commitment from the Krau Institute of Biodiversity and other relevant forestry training institutes to institutionalize it. 13) 5 forestry and state park officers from each of the targeted states empowered under the Wildlife Conservation Act and trained. Wildlife officers are empowered under the Wildlife Conservation Act 2010. The empowerment should be for the forestry and state park officers. 14) A data sharing agreement developed and established between FDPM, DWNP and FRIM July 2022 As a matter of governance, it was agreed in the PSC 1/2020 that an agreement to share data between agencies under KeTSA was not necessary. Instead, the agreement to share data between agencies can be made through an official letter. 15) A standard training programme (Basic, Intermediate, Advanced) for sustainable forest landscape management within the CFS established and mainstreamed into 3 CFS implementing agencies within each targeted state 16) One financial mechanism from the CFS sustainable finance plan included in the state budget of Pahang for 2024.
